Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Cooperative Sensing and Communications for Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The emerging cognitive radio network (CRN) paradigm has a great potential to solve what seems to be a spectrum crisis, by allowing the unlicensed or secondary users (SUs) to opportunistically and dynamically utilize the white spaces within the licensed bands, without causing harmful interference to the licensed or primary users (PUs). This research investigates two essential components of CRNs: spectrum sensing and spectrum access and sharing. More specifically, the PIs study: 1) novel integrated signal processing and communication designs for data fusion in cooperative spectrum sensing, and 2) novel cooperative spectrum sharing and communication schemes that benefit both PUs and SUs.

In contrast to the existing data fusion rules that assume error-free communication channels with capacity constraints, this research involves novel integrated designs that consider the deteriorating effects of communication channels between the radios and the fusion point and therefore are robust against channel errors and provide higher detection reliability. The robustness can further be improved by employing distributed space-time coding and harvesting diversity gain. Novel cooperative communication schemes are developed based on modern coding and enable SUs to relay PUs? rateless coded data packets in a fashion that is completely seamless to PUs. The schemes have mutual benefits for both PUs and SUs and differ from the existing ones in which SUs are silent during PUs? transmission. Broader impacts include (1) bonding the research groups from OSU and the UR and enhancing research and education through this partnership, (2) making a significant impact on the theory and practice of CRNs, (3) increasing the participation of under-represented students in PIs? research groups and promoting engineering among high school students, and (4) integrating research and education through development of new courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The emerging cognitive radio network technology has the great potential to solve what it seems to be a spectrum crisis. This project has addressed two essential components of a cognitive radio network: spectrum sensing and spectrum access and sharing. Through an interweaved plan for research and educational activities, we have accomplished the following: 

(1) We have developed novel integrated signal processing and communication designs to enable a reliable cooperative spectrum sensing. The novelty of these designs is the fact that they take into account (i) the statistical correlation among the observations of geographically distributed cognitive radios, (ii) the uncertainty introduced by the erroneous wireless communication channels over which the signals are being transmitted, (iii) the network topology and communication architecture. Incorporating the statistical correlation, the wireless channel uncertainty, and the network topology and communication architecture into the system design process increase the robustness of the design against perturbation due to various impairments (e.g., varying statistical correlation and communication channel quality due to movements of primary users and/or cognitive radios, changes in signal strength, changing positions of active cognitive radios, variations of spectrum holes and available sensing channels).

(2) We have investigated the fundamental limits of information rates that co-existent primary users and cognitive radios can reliably transmit over the bandwidth-limited and power-constrained communication channels, when they access and share the spectrum simultaneously. In particular, we considered the discrete memoryless state-dependent channel setup introduced by Shannon to study the notion of channel states being observed causally by the transmitter. We studied a particular discrete memoryless state dependent cognitive interference channel and derived a new and better outer bound of the regodic capacity region. Also, we considered a fading Gaussian cognitive relay multiple-access channel, consisting of multiple primary transmitters and an active cognitive radio relay that wish to simultaneously communicate with a single destination. We characterized the ergodic capacity region and the optimal power allocation strategies under certain conditions.

The broader impacts of this project go well beyond advancing the theory and practice of evolving cognitive radio networks and technologies. We have disseminated our key findings and generated knowledge to research communities of interest, via publishing in eight peer-reviewed journals and eleven conference proceedings. The gained knowledge throughout this project enabled us to find new and exciting research opportunities in other disciplines, including advanced brain signal processing and mathematical modeling of human auditory system. Furthermore, this project has facilitated training the next generation of scientists and engineers that have joined and will join STEM workforce. During the course of this project, nine talented students (seven graduate and two REU undergraduate students) made significant scientific contributions toward achieving the goals of this project. Four out of these nine individuals have already completed their PhD studies and joined STEM workforce. The remaining five individuals are on their paths to earn their PhD degrees.
